docs.lead_paragraph: Reading Lisa Sanders's literate descriptions of medical mysteries (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 29) and their unraveling, I was given a jolt, particularly by the case of the 27-year-old man, with a wife and young daughter, who became progressively weak from megaloblastic anemia (B12 deficiency). This is a chronic disease, but it was diagnosed in an emergency room. You can only surmise that the patient and his family are among the 40 million to 50 million underinsured or noninsured who go to emergency rooms and receive disjointed and often inappropriate (and certainly very expensive) care from well-meaning but overstressed staff. In this election year it is important for us to consider unraveling the greater mystery: why is the United States the last great country without universal medical insurance? Dennis Greene, M.D. Mayo Clinic Jacksonville, Fla.
docs.abstract: Dr Dennis Green letter on Lisa Sanders Diagnosis column (Feb 29) says major problem in health care system is that uninsured people are forced to use emergency rooms for diagnosis, resulting in disjointed and inappropriate care from overstressed staff; calls for universal coverage
docs.snippet: Reading Lisa Sanders's literate descriptions of medical mysteries (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 29) and their unraveling, I was given a jolt, particularly by the case of the 27-year-old man, with a wife and young daughter, who became progressively weak...

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats called Saturday for an investigation of charges that the Bush administration threatened to fire a top Medicare official if he gave data to Congress showing the high costs of hotly contested Medicare legislation. The official, Richard S. Foster, chief actuary of the Medicare program, said he had been formally told not to provide the information to Congress. Moreover, he said, he was told that ''the consequences of insubordination would be very severe.''

headline.main: Democrats Demand Inquiry Into Charge By Medicare Officer

docs.abstract: Democrats call for investigation of charges that Bush administratino threatened to fire Richard S Foster, Medicare actuary, if he gave data to Congress showing high costs of Medicare legislation; Foster says he received that message from then-Medicare administrator Thomas A Scully; Scully denies threatening Foster, but confirms having told him to withhold certain information from Congress (M)
docs.snippet: Democrats called Saturday for an investigation of charges that the Bush administration threatened to fire a top Medicare official if he gave data to Congress showing the high costs of hotly contested Medicare legislation.    The official, Richard S....

docs.lead_paragraph: I am the noncustodial parent of a sexually active 16-year-old daughter interested in birth control pills. I am for them; her mother, the custodial parent, is not, citing concerns about cancer, weight gain and the temptation, when on the pill, to neglect condoms and thus increase the risk of S.T.D.'s. I do not want to deceive my ex-wife but realize that our daughter could go to the gynecologist on her own. Should I agree to pay the bill and keep it secret from her mother or tell her? Anonymous, Ft. Lee, N.J. As an ethical matter, your daughter's openness and your honesty are admirable. As a practical matter, deception is exhausting and unreliable. Your daughter goes on the pill surreptitiously, her mother goes into her room to tidy up and the result -- a bad teen comedy. Thus, you should pay the bill and tell your wife you've done so.

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 3-14-04: THE ETHICIST

docs.lead_paragraph: Waterbury is looking for about 250 new teachers for the next school year, and it appears there will be no shortage of applicants, despite the warnings issued by the local teachers association. A job fair at the Maloney Interdistrict Magnet School in December attracted about 2,000 candidates, including some who came from as far as Maryland and Massachusetts. They were greeted by school officials and Mayor Michael J. Jarjura, and also by members of the Waterbury Teachers Association, who handed out fliers advising them not to work in the local school system.

headline.main: In Waterbury, Teachers Are Coming, and Going

docs.abstract: Waterbury, Conn, is looking for about 250 new teachers for next school year because of unusually high number of retirements and to staff new Arts Magnet School; sees no shortage of applicants despite warnings issued by Waterbury Teachers Association about working conditions; union is upset about new contract provisions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This aging city is an unexpected epicenter for a high-tech medical arms race. But employers and insurers here say that is just what they are paying for, as doctors, their traditional sources of income squeezed, discover a new one: diagnostic imaging. Instead of sending patients to a radiologist or one of four local hospitals, doctors in Syracuse have been particularly aggressive about installing imaging equipment -- particularly M.R.I. machines -- in their own offices.

headline.main: An M.R.I. Machine For Every Doctor? Someone Has to Pay

docs.abstract: Some doctors in Syracuse have been installing imaging equipment in their offices instead of sending patients to radiologist or hospital; Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn report finds that diagnostic imaging is approaching $100-billion-a-year business nationally, up about 40 percent since 2000; insurers are becoming increasingly concerned about imaging; five counties surrounding Syracuse have 27 magnetic resonance imaging machines, up from 20 just three years ago; radiologists complain that specialists are investing in machines as way to increase their incomes; there are signs that more machines may translate into too much imaging; it is fastest-growing component of physician services in Medicare program; graphs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate confirmed Dr. Mark B. McClellan, President Bush's nominee to run Medicare and Medicaid, on Friday, after the Senate majority leader promised to help develop legislation to allow imports of lower-cost prescription drugs, with safeguards to protect consumers. The nomination was approved without a roll-call vote.

headline.main: Senate Backs Medicare Pick After Promise On Imports

docs.lead_paragraph: WHENEVER you watch the videotape of Red Sox catcher Carlton Fisk waving his fly ball fair for a home run in Game 6 of the 1975 World Series, do you remember that Pat Darcy was the Cincinnati Reds' pitcher in that 12th inning? Do you remember Dave Stenhouse, a Washington Senators right-hander who was the American League starter in 1962's second All-Star Game?

docs.lead_paragraph: ''If it ain't broke, why fix it?'' That was one widespread reaction to the Bush administration's proposal for financing an enlarged variety of religion-based programs addressing public problems. The government, critics said, had already worked out satisfactory ways, quite in accord with the Constitution's guarantees of freedom of religion and church-state separation, to accommodate or in some instances even finance religiously sponsored organizations providing services like health care, social work, emergency food and shelter, higher education and charities of all kinds.

headline.main: Beliefs; Religious organizations have long had a role in providing social services to the needy. Does a new California law threaten it?

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Bombings in Madrid Kill 192, Injure 1,400 Ten bombs exploded during the morning rush hour in three commuter train stations in Madrid, killing at least 192 people and wounding more than 1,400. Spanish authorities initially blamed the Basque separatist group ETA, but later held open the possibility of militant Islamic terrorism. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: OBESITY is our medical buzzword for the day: has to be. After all, the House of Representatives has just approved the so-called cheeseburger bill -- pretty whimsical nickname given this week's release of a government report declaring fat second only to tobacco as a harbinger of preventable morbidity -- a slice of legislation that prevents tubby consumers from suing restaurants for making them obese. The prevailing opinion? People, not French fries, should be accountable for their flab. Barbra E. Minch, the tempest-in-a-teapot type who is president of the William F. Ryan Community Health Center on West 97th Street, is just relieved to see obesity making headlines.

headline.main: At Health Center, Fighting Obesity Is No Joke

docs.abstract: Robin Finn Public Lives column discusses William F Ryan Community Health Center president Barbra E Minch, who is hoping to educate people on dangers of obesity and have government funding pay to help eradicate disease; photo (M)
